encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Chartley Boyster Sencer Haringfield Luce Father Wise Woman Countryman Taber Joseph Kitchin 2 Luce/Jack The Woman Sir Harry Gratiana Sir Boniface Servingman Old Chartley Gyles Anne All

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enter, as newly come from play, foure young Gentlemen, Master Chartley, Master Sencer, M. Boyster, and Master Haringfield.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.l:
Price of my life: now if the Devil have bones,
these Dice are made of his. Was ever such a
cast seen in this Age? Could any Gull in Europe
(saving myself ) fling such a cast?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: But I say no: I have lost an hundred pound,
And I will have my saying.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: I have lost an other hundred, I will have mine.
Aye, yes, I flung a worse: a worse by odds.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: I cry you mercy sir, losers may speak,
I will not except against you: but let me see
Which of these two that pocket up our Cash
Dares contradict me?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Sir, not I:
I say you have had bad casting.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: So say I.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: I say this Hat is not made of wool.
Which of you all dares say the contrary?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: It may be it is a Beaver.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p:
Very likely so: it is not Wool, but a plain
Beaver.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
It is Wool, but which of you dares say so? I
would fain pick a quarrel with them, to get some of my
money again; but the slaves now they have got it, are too
wise to part with it.
I say it is not black.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: So say we too.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
It is false: his Cap is of Wool, it is black, and
Wool, and Wool and black.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: I have nought to say to losers.
Have I nothing left to set at a Cast? By finger,
Must you be set in gold, and not a jot of silver in my purse?
A Bale of fresh Dice. Ho, come at this Ring.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Fie Master Chartley, it is time to give over.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
That is the Winners phrase: Hold me play,
Or he that hath uncrowned me, I will take a speedy order
with him.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Fresh dice: this Jewel I will venture more,
Take this and all. He play in spite of luck.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: Since you will needs; trip for the Dice.
I see it is hard to go a winner from this company.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: The Dice are mine:
This Diamond I value at twenty marks:
I will venture it at a throw.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: It is set you.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Then at all. All is mine. Nay Master Boyster,
I bar you: let us work upon the winners.
sp.p:
Gramercy Sinks: Nay, though I owe you no quarrel, yet
you must give me leave to draw.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: I had rather you should draw your sword,
Than draw my money thus.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Again sweet Dice: nay I bar swearing,
Gentlemen, let us play patiently. Well, this
At the Candlestick, so --

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Now Dice at all. To thou, quoth the Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Here is precious luck.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Why Via. I think it is Quick-silver;
It goes and comes so fast: there is life in this.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: He passes all with Trays.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: With Trays, how say by that?
O he is old dog at Bowls and Trays.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: Lend me some money: be my half one Cast.
I will once out-brave this Gamester with a throw.
So now the Dice are mine, wilt be my half?

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: Then once I will play the Frank Gamester.
Let me but see how much you both can make,
And I will cast at all, all, every Cross.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Now bless us all, what will you every Cross?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: I will not leave myself one Cross to bless me.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: I set.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: Why then at all. How!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Nay, swear not, let us play patiently.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: Damned Dice: did ever Gamester see the like?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Never, never.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Was ever known such Casting?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Drunk nor sober, I never saw a man cast worse.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: I will prove this Hat of mine an Helmet.
Which of you here dares say the contrary?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: As fair an Helmet as any man in Europe
Needs to wear.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: Chartley, thy Hat is black.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Upon better recollection, it is so indeed.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: I say it is made of Wool.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: True, my losing had took away my Senses,
Both of Seeing and Feeling: but better luck
Hath brought them to their right temper.
But come, a pox of Dice; it is time to give over.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: All times are times for winners to give over,
But not for them that lose. I will play till midnight,
But I will change my luck.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall not.
Give over: tush give over: do I pray,
And choose the Fortune of some other hour:
let us not like debauched fellows, play our Clothes,
Belts, Rapiers, nor our needful ornaments:
It is childish, not becoming Gentlemen.
Play was at first ordained to pass the time;
And sir, you but abuse the use of Play,
To employ it otherwise.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: You may persuade me ~~
For once I will leave a looser.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Then come put on your Helmet; let us leave this
abominable Game, and find out some better Exercise. I cannot
endure this chafing when men loose.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
And there is not a more testy waspish Companion
than thyself when thou art a looser, and yet thou must be
vexing others with, Play patiently Gentlemen, and let us have
no swearing.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
A sign that I can give good counsel better than
take it: but say, Where be the prettiest wenches, my hearts?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Well remembered, this puts me in mind of an appointment
I had with a Gentlewoman of some respect.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
I have you sir, I have you; but I think you will never
have her: it is Gratiana the Knights daughter in Gracious
Street. Have I touched you?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
You have come somewhat near me, but touched me
not. Master Haringfield, will you bear me company thither?
Have you seen the Gentlewoman, Master Chartley?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Never sir.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: How have you heard of her?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: That she hath, as other women have,
That she goes for a Maid, as others do, etc.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: I can assure you, she is a proper Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Then if she have you, she is like to have a proper
Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: You should tell them so that know it not.
Adiew Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: I am glad yet they go so lightly away.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: What will you do Master Boyster!

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Somewhat.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: You will not acquaint me with your business.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
No: I am in love, my head is full of Proclamations.
There is a thing called a Virgin. Nature hath showed
Her Art in making her. Court her I cannot, but I will do as
I may.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Do you go, or stay sir?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
You before, I will follow. He thinks with his blunt
humour, to enter as far as I with my sharpe: No, my true
Trojan, no: There is a fair sweet modest rogue, her name
is Luce: with this Dandiprat, this pretty little Apes face, is
yon blunt fellow in love; and no marvel, for she hath a
Brow bewitching, Eyes ravishing, and a Tongue enchanting:
And indeed she hath no fault in the world but
one, and that is, she is honest: and were it not for that,
she were the only sweet Rogue in Christendom. As I
live, I love her extremely, and to enjoy her would give
anything: But the fool stands in her own light, and
will do nothing without Marriage: but what should I
do marrying? I can better endure Gives, than Bands of
Matrimony. But in this Meditation, I am glad I have
won my Money again. Nay, and she may be glad of it
too: for the Girl is but poor, and in my pocket I have
laid up a Stock for her, it is put to use already. And if I
meet not with a Dice-house, or an Ordinary by the way,
no question but I may increase it to a sum. Well, I will
unto the Exchange to buy her some pretty Novelty: That
done, I will visit my little Rascal, and solicit instantly.

body.stage: Enter Luce in a Sempsters shop, at work vpon a lac'd Handkercher, and Joseph a Prentice.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Where is my Father? Ioseph.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.l: Mistress, above,
And prays you to attend below a little.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I do not love to sit thus publicly:
And yet upon the traffic of our Wares,
Our provident Eyes and presence must still wait.
Do you attend the shop, I will ply my work.
I see my father is not jealous of me,
That trusts me to the open view of all.
The reason is, he knows my thoughts are chaste,
And my care such, as that it needs the awe
Of no strict Overseer.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Yonder is Luce. Save thee.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: And you too, sir, ye are welcome; want you ought,
I pray, in which our Trade may furnish you?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Ioseph, show the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: It is here that I would buy.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What do you mean sir, speak, what is it you lack?
I pray you wherefore do you fix your eyes
So firmly in my face? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Thee.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Yes, thee.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Your pleasure is to jest, and so I take it.
Pray give me leave sir, to intend my work.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: You are fair.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: You flout me.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: You are, go to you are,
I would vex him that should say the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Well, you may say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: I love thee.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O Sir!

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: As I live, I do.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Now as I am a true Maid,
The most religious oath that I dare swear,
I hold myself indebted to your love:
And I am sorry there remains in me,
No power how to requite it.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Love me, prithee now, do if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Prithee, if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Indeed I cannot.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Yet ask thine heart, and see what may be done.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: In troth I am sorry you should spend a sigh
For my sake unrequited, or a tear;
Aye, or a word.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: It is no matter for my words, they are not many,
And those not very wise one's neither.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yet I beseech you spend no more in vain.
I scorn you not; Disdain is as far from me,
As are the two Poles distant: therefore Sir,
Because I would not hold you in suspense,
But tell you what at first to trust unto,
Thus in a word, I must not fancy you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Must not?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I cannot, nor I may not.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: I am gone:
Thou hast given me, Luce, a Bone to gnaw upon?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Alas, that Beauty should be sought of more
Than can enjoy it: might I have my wish,
I would seem fair but only in his eye,
That should possess me in a Nuptial tie.

body.stage: Enter young Master Chartley, with Gloves, Ring, Purse, etc.

sp.speaker: Chartl.
sp.p:
Morrow Luce; In exchange of this kiss, see
what I have brought thee from the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: What mean you Sir, by this?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Guess that by the circumstance, here is a Ring,
wear it for my sake; twenty Angels, pocket them you
fool; come, come, I know thou art a Maid, say nay, and
take them.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sweet Master Chartley, do not fasten on me,
More than with ease I can shake off: your Gift
I reverence, yet refuse; and I pray tell me,
Why do you make so many Errands hither?
Send me so many Letters? fasten on me
So many favours? what is your meaning in it?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Hark in thine ear, I will tell thee; nay hear me out,
is it possible so soft a body should have so hard a soul? Nay
now I know my penance, you will be angry, and school me
for tempting your modesty: a fig for this modesty, it hinders
many a good man from many a good turn, and that is all
the good it doth. If thou but knewest, Luce, how I love thee,
thou wouldst be far more tractable. Nay, I bar chiding
when you speak. I will stop thy lips if thou dost but offer an
angry word, by this hand I will do it, and with this hand too.
Go to now, what say you?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sir, if you love me, as you say you do,
Show me the fruits thereof.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: The stock I can, thou mayst see the fruits hereafter.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Can I believe you love me, when you seek
The shipwreck of mine Honour?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Honour! there is another word to flap in a man's
mouth: Honour! what shouldst thou and I stand upon our
Honour, that were neither of us yet, Right Worshipful?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I am sorry Sir, I have lent so large an ear
To such a bad discourse; and I protest
After this hour, never to do the like.
I must confess, of all the Gentlemen
That ever courted me, you have possessed
The best part in my thoughts: but this course language
Exiles you quite from thence. Sir, had you come,
In stead of changing this mine honest name
Into a Strumpets, to have honoured me
With the chaste Title of a Modest Wife;
I had reserved an ear for all your suits:
But since I see your rudeness finds no limit,
I leave you to your lust.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: You shall not, Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
Then keep your tongue within more moderate
bounds.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
I will, as I am virtuous, I will: I told you, the
second word would be Marriage. It makes a man forfeit
his Freedom, and makes him walk ever after with a
Chain at his heels, or a Iack-an-Apes hanging at his elbow:
Marriage is like Daedalus his labyrinth, and being
once in, there is no finding the way out. Well, I love this
little property most intolerably, and I must set her on the
Last, though it cost me all the shoes in my shop. Well
Luce, thou seest my stomach is come down; thou hast my
heart already, there is my hand.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: But in what way?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Nay, I know not the way yet, but I hope to find
it hereafter, by your good direction.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I mean, in what manner? in what way?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
In the way of marriage, in the way of honesty, in
the way that was never gone yet: I hope thou art a Maid,
Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and I accept it; in exchange
Of this your hand, you shall receive my heart.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p:
A bargain, and there is earnest on thy
lips.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I will call my Father, Sir, to witness it:
See, here he comes.

body.stage: Enter her Father, a plain Citizen.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Father, save you, you have happened of an untoward
Son-in-Law; here I am, how do you like me?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Sir, I was nearer than you were aware,
And over-heard both sum and circumstance.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Then I perceive you are an old Eves-dropper:
But what do you think of it, Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: I entertain the motion with all love,
And I rejoice my Daughter is preferred,
And raised to such a match; I heard the contract,
And will confirm it gladly: but pray Sir,
When shall the merry day be?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Marry, even tomorrow by that we can see; nay,
we will lose no more time, I will take order for that.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Stay but a month.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
A month Aye thou canst not hire me to it. Why
Luce, if thou beest hungry, canst thou stay a month from
meat? Nay, if I see my diet before me, I love to fall too
when I have a stomach. Here, buy thee a new Smock;
let us have a new Bed too, and look it be strong: there is a
box of Rings and Jewels, lay them up. Ha sirrah, methinks
the very name of Wedlock hath brought me to a Night-cap
already, and I am grown civil on the sudden. There is
more money for Dishes, Platters, Ladles, Candlesticks, etc.
as I shall find them set down in the Inventory.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: But whom shall we invite unto the Wedding?

body.stage: Enter 2d. Luce, a young Country Gentlewoman, in the habit of a Page, and overhears their discourse.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Aye, thereby hangs a Tale, we will have no more
at our marriage, but myself, to say, I take thee Luce; thou
to say, I Luce take thee Robin: the Vicar to put us together,
and you Father, to play the Clerk, and cry Amen.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Your reason for that.

sp.speaker: Chartl.
sp.p:
I would not for a world it should be known
To my Friends, or come to my Fathers ear. It may
be ten thousand pounds out of my way for the present:
therefore this is my conceit, Let us be married
privately, and Luce shall live like a Maid still, and
bear the Name. It is nothing Luce: it is a common thing
in this age to go for a Maid, and be none. I will frequent
the house secretly: fear not Girl, though I revel abroad
a days, I will be with thee to bring a nights, my little Whiting
Mop.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But so I may incur a public scandal,
By your so oft frequenting to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Scandal? what scandal? Why to stop the
mouth of all scandal, after some few days do I appear
in my likeness, married man and honest house-keeper,
and then what becomes of your scandal? Come, send for
Mr. Vicar, and what we do, let us do suddenly.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Cold comfort for me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
If you purpose to be so privately married, I know
one excellent at such an exploit: are you not acquainted
with the Wise-woman of Hogsdon?

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p:
O the Witch, the Beldam, the Hag of
Hogsdon.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
The same, but I hold her to be of no such condition.
I will anon make a steppe thither, and punctually
acquaint her with all our proceedings: she is
never without a Sir Iohn at her elbow, ready for such
a stratagem.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Well, be it so then.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Heigh ho: have I disguised myself, and
stolen out of the Country thus far, and can light of
no better news to entertain me? O this wild-headed
wicked Chartley, whom nothing will tame. To this
Gallant was I poor Gentle-woman betrothed, and the
Marriage day appointed: But he out of a fantastic and
giddy humour, before the time prefixed, posts up to London.
After him come I thus habited, and you see my
welcome, to be an ear witness of his second Contracting.
Modesty would not suffer me to discover myself,
otherwise, I should have gone near to have marred the
match. I heard them talk of Hogsdon, and a Wise-woman,
where these Aims shall be brought to Action.
I will see if I can insinuate myself into her service: that is
my next project: and now good luck of my side.

body.stage: Enter the Wise-woman and her Clyents, a Countrey-man with an Vrinall, foure Women like Citizens wives, Taber a Serving-man, and a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.l: Fie, fie, what a toil, and a moil it is,
For a woman to be wiser than all her neighbours?
I pray good people, press not too fast upon me;
Though I have two ears, I can hear but one at once.
You with the Urine.

sp.speaker: Countryman.
sp.l: Here forsooth Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: And who distilled this water?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.l: My wives Limbeck, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: And where doth the pain hold her most?

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.l: Marry at her heart forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
Aye, at her heart, she hath a griping at her
heart.

sp.speaker: Countr.
sp.p: You have hit it right.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Nay, I can see so much in the Urine.

sp.speaker: 2 Luce.
sp.p: Just so much as is told her.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: She hath no pain in her head, hath she?

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.p:
No indeed, I never heard her complain of
her head.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.l: I told you so, her pain lies all at her heart:
Alas good heart! but how feels she her stomach?

sp.speaker: Countrym.
sp.l: O queasy, and sick at stomach.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Aye, I warrant you, I think I can see as far
into a Mill-stone as another: you have heard of Mother
Notingham, who for her time, was prettily well skilled
in casting of Waters: and after her, Mother Bombye;
and then there is one Hatfield in Pepper-Alley, he doth
pretty well for a thing that is lost. There is another in
Coal harbour, that is skilled in the Planets. Mother Sturton
in Golden-lane, is for Forespeaking: Mother Phillips
of the Bankside, for the weakness of the back: and
then there is a very reverent Matron on Clarkenwell-Green,
good at many things: Mistress Mary on the Bankside,
is for erecting a Figure: and one (what do you call
her) in Westminster, that practiseth the Book and the Key,
and the Sieve and the Shears: and all do well, according
to their talent. For myself, let the world speak: hark
you my friend, you shall take --

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: It is strange the Ignorant should be thus fooled.
What can this Witch, this Wizard, or old Trot,
Do by Enchantment, or by Magic spell?
Such as profess that Art should be deep Scholars.
What reading can this simple Woman have?
It is palpable gross foolery.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.l: Now friend, your business?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
I have stolen out of my Masters house, forsooth,
with the kitchen-maid, and I am come to know of you,
whether it be my fortune to have her, or no.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: And what is your suit, Lady?

sp.speaker: Kitchin.
sp.p:
Forsooth, I come to know whether I be a
Maid or no.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Why, art thou in doubt of that?

sp.speaker: Kitchin.
sp.p:
It may be I have more reason than all the
world knows.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Nay, if thou comest to know whether thou beest
a Maid or no, I had best ask to know whether I be with
child or no.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
Withdraw into the Parlour there, I will but talk
with this other Gentlewoman, and He resolve you presently.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Come Sisly, if she cannot resolve thee, I can,
and in the Case of a Maidenhead do more than she,
I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: The Wom.
sp.p: Forsooth I am bold, as they say.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You are welcome Gentlewoman.--

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
I would not have it known to my Neighbours,
That I come to a Wise-woman for anything, by my
truly.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p:
For should your Husband come and find
you here.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: My Husband woman, I am a Widow.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p:
Where are my brains? it is true, you are a
Widow; and you dwell, let me see, I can never remember
That place.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: In Kent street.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p:
Kent street, Kent street! and I can tell you wherefore
you come.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Why, and say true?

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p:
You are a Wag, you are a Wag: why,
what do you think now I would say?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p:
Perhaps, to know how many Husbands I should
have.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p: And if I should say so, should I say amiss?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I think you are a Witch.

sp.speaker: Wisewom.
sp.p:
In, in, I will but read a little of Ptolomie, and
Erra Pater; and when I have cast a Figure, I will come to you
presently.
Now Wag, what wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
If this were a Wise-woman, she could tell
That without asking. Now methinks I should come to
know whether I were a Boy or a Girl; forsooth I lack
a service.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: By my Fidelity, and I want a good trusty Lad.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Now could I sigh, and say, Alas, this is some
Bawd trade-fallen, and out of her wicked experience, is
come to be reputed wise. I will serve her, be it but to pry into
the mystery of her Science.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
A proper stripling, and a wise, I warrant him;
here is a penny for thee, I will hire thee for a year by the Statute
of Winchester: prove true and honest, and thou shalt want
nothing that a good Boy --

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Here Wise-woman you are out again, I shall
want what a good Boy should have, whilst I live: well,
here I shall live both unknown, and my Sex unsuspected.
But whom have we here?

body.stage: Enter Master Haringfield, and Chartley half drunk.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Come Haringfield, now we have been drinking
of Mother Red-caps Ale, let us now go make some
sport with the Wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p:
We shall be thought very wise men, of all such
as shall see us go in to the Wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Chartley.
sp.p:
See, here she is; how now Witch? How
now Hag? How now Beldam? You are the Wise-woman,
are you? and have wit to keep yourself warm
enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Out thou knave.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: And will these wild oats never be sown?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
You Enchantress, Sorceress, She-devil; you
Madam Hecate, Lady Proserpine, you are too old, you
Hag, now, for conjuring up Spirits yourself; but you
keep pretty young Witches under your roof, that can do
that.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Aye, or my Family conjure up any Spirits! I defy
thee, thou young Hare-brained --

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p:
Forbear him till he have his Senses about him,
and I shall then hold thee for a Wise-woman indeed:
otherwise, I shall doubt thou hast thy name for nothing,
Come friend, away, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Away you old Dromedary, I will come one of
these nights, and make a racket amongst your She-Caterwaulers.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.p: I prithee let us be civil.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Out of my sight, thou She-mastif.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Patience, sweet Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Now bless me, he hath put me into such a
fear, as makes all my bones to dance, and rattle in my skin:
I will be revenged on that swaggering companion.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Mistress, I wish you would, he is a mere Madcap,
and all his delight is in misusing such reverent Matrons
as yourself.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Well, what is thy name, Boy?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
I am even little better than a Turn-broach,
For my name is Iacke.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Honest Iacke, if thou couldst but devise how I
might cry quittance with this cutting Dicke, I will go
near to adopt thee my Son and heir.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: Mistress, there is a way, and this it is;
tomorrow morning doth this Gentleman
Intend to marry with one Mistress Luce,
A Gold-smiths Daughter; do you know the Maid?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.l: My Daughter, and a pretty smug faced Girl.
I had a note but late from her, and she means
To be with me in the evening; for I have bespoke
Sir Boniface to marry her in the morning.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: do but prevent this Gallant of his Wife,
And then your wrongs shall be revenged at full.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
I will do it, as I am Matron; Aye, and show him a
new trick for his learning.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Ye are welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Art wise?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
he should be wise, because he speaks few
words.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: I am as I am, and there is an end.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Canst conjure?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
O that is a foul word! but I can tell you your
Fortune, as they say; I have some little skill in Palmistry,
but never had to do with the devil.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
And had the devil never anything to do with
thee? thou lookest somewhat like his dam. Look on
me canst tell what I ail?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Can you tell yourself? I should guess, you be
mad, or not well in your wits.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Thou art wise, I am so; men being in love, are mad,
And I being in love, am so.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Nay, if I see your complexion once, I think I
can guess as near as another.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: One Mistress Luce I love, knowest thou her, Grannam?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
As well as the Beggar knows his Dish. Why
she is one of my Daughters.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Make her my wife, I will give thee forty pieces.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: Take them Mistress, to be revenged on Chartley.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: A bargain, strike me luck, cease all your sorrow,
Fair Luce shall be your Bride betimes tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Thou art a good Grannam; and, but that thy teeth stand
Like hedge-stakes in thy head, I would kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.l: Pray will you in; come hither lack, I have
A new trick come into my head, wilt thou
Assist me in it?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: If it concern the crossing of the marriage with
Mistress Luce, I will do it what ever it be.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Thou shalt be tired like a woman; can you
make a courtesy, take small strides, simper, and see me modest?
methinks thou hast a woman's voice already.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Doubt not of me, I will act them naturally.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
I have conceited, to have Luce married to this
blunt Gentleman; she mistaking him for Chartley, and
Chartley shall marry thee, being a Boy, and take thee for
Luce. Wilt not be excellent?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: O super, super-excellent!

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Play but thy part, as I will act mine, I will fit him
with a Wife, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: And a Wife I will warrant him.

body.stage: Enter Old Sir Harry, and his man Taber.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
Ha, then thou sawest them whispering with
my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I saw them, if it shall please you, not whisper, but --

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: How then, thou knave?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Marry Sir Knight, I saw them in sad talk; but
To say they were directly whispering, I am not able.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why Taber, that sad talk was whispering.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Nay, they did not greatly whisper, for I heard
what was said, and what was said, I have the wit to keep
to myself.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
What said the unthrift, Taber, tell me knave?
Tell me, good knave, what did the unthrift say?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
I am loath to be called in question about men and
women's matters, but as soon as ever he saw your Daughter,
I heard what was spoke.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
Here sirrah, take thy Quarters wages afore-hand,
and tell me all their words, and what their greeting was at
their first encounter; hold thine hand.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Thanks, Noble Sir, and now I will tell you. Your
daughter being walking to take the air of the fields, and I
before her; whom should we meet just in the nick?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Just in the nick, man?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: In the high-way I meant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
Ha, and what conference past betwixt them,
Taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
As well as my Pipe can utter, you shall know Sir.
This Gentleman meeting with my young Mistress full butt;
imagine you were she, and I young Master Sencer; now there
you come, and here I meet you; he comes in this manner, and
put off his hat in this fashion.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Aye, but what said he?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Be with you, fair Gentlewoman; and so goes
quite away, and scarce so much as once looked back: and
if this were language to offer to a young Lady, judge you.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: But spake he nothing else?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Nothing as I am true.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why man, all this was nothing.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, it was as much as my Quarters wages
afore-hand.

body.stage: Enter Master Sencer, Master Haringfield, and Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Here are two Gentlemen with great desire,
Crave conference with my Father: here he is,
Now Gallants, you may freely speak, your minds.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Save you Sir, my name is Sencer; I am a Northampton-shire
Gentleman, born to a thousand pound Land by the
year: I love your Daughter, and I am come to crave your
good-will.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Have you my Daughters, that you covet mine?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: No Sir, but I hope in time I shall have.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
So hope not I. Sir, Sir, my Daughter is young,
and you a Gentleman unknown, Sencer? ha, Sencer? O Sir,
your name I now remember well, it is ranked amongst unthrifts,
dicers, swaggerers, and drunkards: were not you
brought before me, some month since, for beating of the
Watch, by the same token, I sent you to the Counter?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
I confess myself to have been in that action, but
note the cause, Sir: you could not have pleasured me so
much, in giving me a piece of gold, as at the same time to
help me to that Counter.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
Why Sir, what cause had you to beat the Watch,
and raise a midnight tumult in the streets?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Nay, but hear me, sweet Sir Harry: Being
somewhat late at Supper at the Mitre, the doors were
shut at my Lodging, I knocked at three or four places
more, all were a-bed, and fast: Inns, Taverns, none
would give me entertainment. Now, would you have had
me despaired, and lain in the streets? No, I bethought me
of a trick worth two of that, and presently devised, having
at that time a charge of money about me, to be lodged,
and safely too.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: As how, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Marry thus: I had knocked my heels against the
ground a good while, knew not where to have a Bed for
love nor money. Now what did I? but spying the Watch,
went and hit the Constable a good souse on the Ear, who
provided me of a lodging presently; and the next day, being
brought before your Worship, I was then sent thither
back again, where I lay three or four days without
control.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: O, ye are a Gallant! is that Gentleman
A Suitor too?

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: I am a Suitor in my friends behalf,
No otherwise: I can assure you, Sir,
He is a Gentleman descended well,
Derived from a good house, well qualified,
And well possessed; but that which most should move you,
he loves your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: But were I to choose,
Which of these two should please my fancy best,
I sooner should affect this Gentleman,
For his mild carriage, and his fair discourse,
Than my hot Suitor; Ruffians I detest:
A smooth and square behaviour likes me best.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: What say you to me, Lady.

sp.speaker: Gratian.
sp.p:
You had best ask my Father what I should
say.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Are you angry, sweet Lady, that I asked your Fathers
consent?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p:
No, if you can get his consent to marry him, shall
it displease me?

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: Indeed you therein much forget yourself,
To sound her Father ere you tasted her.
You should have first sought means for her good-will,
And after compassed his.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: He can prevail with neither: Gentlemen,
If you will come to revel, you are welcome;
If to my Table, welcome; if to use me
In any grateful Office, welcome too:
But if you come as Suitors, there is the door.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: The door!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: I say the door.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Why Sir? tell not me of your door, nor going
out of it, your company is fair and good, and so is your
Daughters; I will stay here this twelvemonth, ere I will offer
To trouble your door.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
Sir, but you shall not. Taber! where is that
knave?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Why Sir, I hope you do not mean to make us
dance, that you call for a Taber.

sp.speaker: Haring.
sp.l: Nay Master Sencer, do not urge the Knight,
he is incensed now, choose a fitter hour,
And tempt his love in that: old men are testy,
Their rage, if stood against, grows violent;
But suffered and forborne, confounds itself.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Where is Taber!

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.l: At hand, noble Master.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Show them the door.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
That I will, and take money too, if it please
them.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Is thy name Taber?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: I am so yclept Sir.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
And Taber, are you appointed to give us Iacke
Drum's entertainment?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Why sir, you do not play upon me.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Though I cannot, yet I have known an Hare
That could. But Knight, thou dost not forbid us thine
House.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Yes, and forewarn it too.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
But by thy favour, we may choose whether we
will take any warning or no. Well, farewell old Knight,
though thou forbiddest me thine house, I will honour thee,
and extol thee; and though thou keepest me from thy
Daughter, thou shalt not hinder me to love her, and admire
Her: and by thy favour, sometimes to see her: A
Cat may look at a King, and so may I at her. Give me
thine hand, Knight, the next time I come into thy company,
thou shalt not only bid me welcome, but hire me to stay
with thee, and thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir. Har.
sp.l: When I do that, enjoy my full consent,
To marry Graciana.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: It is a match, strike me luck:
Wife that may be, farewell: Father in law that
Must be, adieu. Taber, play before, my friend
And I will dance after.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: When I receive thee gladly to mine house,
And wage thy stay, thou shalt have Graciana,
Doubt not, thou shalt. here is a strange Humorist,
To come a wooing. Taber, are they gone?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p:
I have played them away, if it please your Worship;
and yonder at the door attends a Schoolmaster, you sent
for him, if you remember, to teach my little young Master
and Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: A proper Scholar, pray him to come near.

body.stage: Enter a pedantical Schoolmaster, Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p:
Eques Honoratus: Ave sulutatus: non vides
quid est in Tergo, sed salve bona virgo.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
Sir, you may call menick-names: if you love
me, speak, in your Mother-tongue; or at the least, if Learning
be so much allied unto you, that Latin unawares
flows from your lips: to make your mind familiar with
my knowledge, pray utter it in English: what is your name?

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.l: Sit faustum tibi omen.
I will tell you my Nomen.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Will you tell it to no men.
I will entertain none ere I know their names:
Nay, if you be so dainty of your name,
You are not for my service.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.l: Intende vir nobilis.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Not for twenty Nobles:
Trust me, I will not buy your name so dear.

sp.speaker: Sir Bon.
sp.l: O Ignorantia! what it is to deal with stupidity?
Sir Henry, Sir Henry, hear me one word,
I see, Preceptor legit, vos vero negligitis.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p:
I think he saith we are a company of fools, and
Midgets, but I hope you shall not find us such, Master Schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Friend, friend, to cut off all vain circumstance,
Tell me your name, and answer me directly,
Plainly, and to my understanding too,
Or I shall leave you: here is a deal of gibberish.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.l: Vir bone.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Nay, nay, make me no bones, but do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.l: Then in plain vulgar English I am called,
Sir Boniface Absee.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Why this is somewhat like, Sir Boniface,
Give me thine hand, thou art a proper man,
And in my judgment, a great Scholar too:
What shall I give thee by the year?

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.l: I will trust, Sir, to your generosity;
I will not bargain, but account myself
Mille et mille modis, bound to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: I cannot leave my Mils, they are farmed already,
The stipend that I give, shall be in money.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Sure Sir, this is some Miller that comes to undermine
you, in the shape of a Schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You both mistake the Scholar.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: I understand my English, that I know;
What is more than Modern, doth surpass my reach.
Sir Boniface, come to me two days hence,
You shall receive an answer; I have now,
Matters of some import that trouble me,
Thou shouldst be else dispatched.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Sir Boniface, if you come to live in our house, and
be a Familist amongst us, I shall desire you better acquaintance,
your Name and my Physiognomy should have some consanguinity,
good Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Quomodo vales, quomodo vales.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Go with you to the Ale-house? I like the motion
well; I will make an excuse out of doors and follow you.
I am glad yet, we shall have a Good-fellow come into the
house amongst us.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Vale vir magno.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
You shall not have me at Saint Magnes, my
house is here in Gracious-street.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.l: I know it, sweet Knight, I know it.
Then virgo formosa, and Domine gratiose valete.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Aye, in Gracious-street you shall hear of me,
Sir Boniface, He shall instruct my children; and to thee,
Fair Gratiana, read the Latin tongue.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.l: Who, shall Sir Bawdy-face?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Sir Boniface, you fool.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.l: His name is so hard to hit on.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.l: Come Daughter, if things fall out as I intend,
My thoughts shall peace have, and these troubles end.

body.stage: Enter the second Luce, which was Iack in woman's apparell, and the Wise-woman.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Iack, thou art my Boy.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Mistress!

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
I will be a Mother to thee, no Mistress: come Lad,
I must have thee sworn to the orders of my house, and the
secrets thereof.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
As I am an honest Lad, I am yours to command.
But Mistress, what mean all these women's pictures,
hanged here in your withdrawing room?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
I will tell thee, Boy; marry thou must be secret.
When any Citizens, or young Gentlemen come hither, under
a colour to know their Fortunes, they look upon these pictures,
and which of them they best like, she is ready with a
wet finger: here they have all the furniture belonging to a
private-chamber, bed, bed-fellow and all; but mum, thou
knowest my meaning, Iacke.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
But I see coming and going, Maids, or such
is go for Maids, some of them, as if they were ready to lie
down, sometimes two or three delivered in one night; then
suddenly leave their Brats behind them, and convey
themselves into the City again: what becomes of their
Children?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Those be Kitchen-maids, and Chamber-maids,
and sometimes good men's Daughters; who having catched
a clap, and growing near their time, get leave to see their
friends in the Country, for a week or so: then hither they
come, and for a matter of money, here they are delivered.
I have a Midwife or two belonging to the house, and one
Sir Boniface a Deacon, that makes a shift to christen the Infants:
we have poor, honest, and secret Neighbours, that
stand for common Gossips. But dost not thou know this?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Yes, now I do: but what after becomes of the
poor Infants?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Why, in the night we send them abroad, and lay
one at this man's door, and another at that, such as are able
to keep them; and what after becomes of them, we inquire
not. And this is another string to my Bow.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: Most strange, that woman's brain should apprehend
Such lawless, indirect, and horrid means
For covetous gain! How many unknown Trades
Women and men are free of, which they never
Had Charter for? but Mistress, are you so
Cunning as you make yourself: you can
Neither write nor read, what do you with those
Books you so often turn over?

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
Why tell the leaves; for to be ignorant, and seem
ignorant, what greater folly?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Believe me, this is a cunning Woman; neither
hath she her name for nothing, who out of her ignorance,
can fool so many that think themselves wise. But wherefore
have you built this little Closet close to the door,
where sitting, you may hear every word spoken, by all
such as ask for you.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
True, and therefore I built it: if any knock, you
must to the door and question them, to find what they come
about, if to this purpose, or to that. Now they ignorantly
telling thee their errand, which I sitting in my Closet, overhear,
presently come forth, and tell them the cause of their
coming, with every word that hath past betwixt you in
private: which they admiring, and thinking it to be miraculous,
by their report I become thus famous.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
This is no Trade, but a Mystery; and were I a
Wise-woman, as indeed I am but a foolish Boy, I need not
live by your service. But Mistress, we lose ourselves in this
discourse, is not this the morning in which I should be
married?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Now, how had I forgot myself? Mistress Luce
promised to be with me half an hour ago, but masked and
disguised, and so shalt thou be too: here is a black Veil to
hide thy face against the rest come.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: Sit tibi bona dies: salus et quies.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Into the withdrawing room, Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p:
Without any compunction, I will make the
Conjunction.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Now keep thy countenance, Boy.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Fear not me, I have as good a face in a Mask,
as any Lady in the Land could wish to have: but to my
heart, he comes, or he comes not; now am I in a pitiful
perplexity, until I see the event of all.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: No more Iacke now, but Mistress Luce.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
I warrant you Mistress: that it happens so luckily,
That my name should be Luce too, to make the marriage
more firm!

body.stage: Enter Chartley disguised, and in a Visard.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: My honey sweet Hag, where is Luce?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
Here sweet heart, but disguised and veiled, as
you are vizarded.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But what is the reason we are thus Hoodwinked?

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
No discovery of yourselves for a million, there is
Sir Boniface within, shall he blab who you are? Besides,
there is a young Heir that hath stolen a Lords Daughter
from the Court, and would not have their faces seen for a
World: cannot you be content to fare well, and keep your
own counsel, and see, yonder they come.

body.stage: Enter at several places, Boyster visarded, and Luce mask's.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Gramercy my Sugar-candy sweet Trot.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p: Mum, no more words.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
If the great Heir and the young Lady be so dainty
of their Complexions, they shall see (my sweet Luce) we
can vizard it with the best of them.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
That Gentleman, by the Wise woman's description,
should be Master Chartley.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: That gallant Wench, if my Grannam fable not,
Should be Luce: but what be those other?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
You wrong me, but to ask, who but a young
Heir, and a Lady of the Court: that is Luce, take her, and
keep your promise.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Pocas palabras.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.l: That Chartley, take him Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But who be they?

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.l: A Lord and Lady shall Sir Boniface stay,
Rather than so, strive who should lead the way.
sp.stage: Exeunt Chartley with Iack, Boyster with Luce.
sp.p:
Now Iack my Boy, keep thine own counsel,
and countenance, and I shall cry quittance with my young
Gallant. Well, by this time Sir Boniface is at his Book.
But because there is a mistake, known only to my
Boy and myself; the Marriage shall be no sooner ended,
but I will disturb them by some sudden out-cry, and that
too, before they have leisure to unmask, and make
known themselves one to another; for if the deceit
were known, I should fall into the danger of that young
mad Rascal. And now this double apprehension of the
Lord and the Lady shall fetch me off from all; I know
it is Sir Boniface his custom, to make short work,
and hath dispatched by this: And now Wise-woman,
try if thou canst bestir thyself like to a Mad-woman --
shift for yourselves, Warrants and Pursuivants! Away,
Warrants and Pursuivants! shift for yourselves.

body.stage: Enter, as affrighted and amazed, Chartley, Boyster, Boniface, and others.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: I will take this way.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I this.

sp.speaker: Bonif.
sp.p:
Curro Curris Cucurri: My cheeks are all Murry,
And I am gone in an hurry.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O Heaven! what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I know what shall become of me already.

sp.speaker: Wisewo.
sp.p:
O sweet Daughter, shift clothes with this
Lady! Nay, as thou lovest thy credit and mine, change
Habits -- So, if thou beest taken in her Garments, finding
the mistake, will let thee pass; and should they meet her
in thine, not knowing her, would no way question her:
and this prove to both your securities and my safety.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: As fast as I can, good Mother: So Madam farewell.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: All happy joys betide you.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, let me hold my sides, and laugh: Here
were even a Plot to make a play of, but that Chartley is
so fooled by my Boy Iacke: Well, he will make a notable
Wag, I will warrant him. All the Jest will be, if
Boyster should meet with him in Luce's habit, which
he hath now on, he would think himself merely
gulled and cheated; and should Chartley meet with Luce
as she is now Robed, he would be confident he had
married her. Let me see how many Trades have I to
live by: First, I am a Wise-woman, and a Fortune teller,
and under that I deal in Physic and Fore-speaking,
in Palmistry, and recovering of things lost. Next,
I undertake to cure Mad folks. Then I keep Gentlewomen
Lodgers, to furnish such Chambers as I let out
by the night: Then I am provided for bringing young
Wenches to bed; and for a need, you see I can play the
Match-maker. She that is but one, and professeth so many,
may well be termed a Wise-woman, if there be
any.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Why, run away, and leave my Wench behind?
I will back: what have Warrants and Pursuivants to do
with me? with me? why should I budge? why should
I wear Mask or Vizard? If Lords or Ladies offend, let
Lords and Ladies answer; let me better bethink me.
Why should I play at Hob-man blind? Hum; why
marry in Tenebris, ha! is there no trick in it? If my
Grannam should make me a younger Brother now, and
instead of Luce, pop me off with some broken commodity,
I were finely served: most sure I am, to be in
For better and worse, but with whom, Heaven and my
Grannam knows.

body.stage: Enter half ready and masked, 2. Luce.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
I am stolen out of doors, to see if I can meet
my Husband; with whom I purpose to make some sport,
ere I suddenly disclose myself: what is he?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Heyday, what have we here, an Hoberdehoy?
come hither you.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: It is Mistress Luces Husband,
I will not leave him thus.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: That Mask and Robe I know.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: I hope so, or else I were in a woe case.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: That Mask, that Gown I married.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Then you have no reason, but to enjoy both them
and me too, and so you are like; I should be loath to divorce
Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
I am fooled, but what cracked ware are you,
forsooth?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
I belong to the old Gentlewoman of the
house.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: I will set her house on fire: I am finely bobbed.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: But I hope you will not bob me.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
No I shall warrant thee: what art thou? Girl
or Boy?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Both, and neither; I was a Lad last night,
but in the morning I was conjured into a Lass: And
being a Girl now, I shall be translated to a Boy anon.
Here is all I can at this time say for myself: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
Yes, and be hanged withal. O for some Gun
powder to blow up this Witch; this She-cat, this
damned Sorceress! O I could tear her to fitters with
my teeth! Yet I must be patient, and put up all, lest I
be made a jeer to such as know me: fooled by a
Boy! Go to of all the rest, the Girl Luce must not
know it.

body.stage: Enter Chartley and his man, meeting Luce.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
So, now am I the same man I was yesterday;
Who can say I was disguised? or who can distinguish my
condition now? or read in my face, whether I be a married
man, or a Bachelor?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Sweet Husband, is it you?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: The news?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Never so frighted in my days.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: What has become of the Lord and the Lady?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
The Lord fled after you, the Lady staid; who
masked, and half unready, ran fast after her poor affrighted
Husband: now all is quiet.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
This storm is then well past, and now convey
yourself home as privately as you can: and see you make
this known to none but your Father.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I am your Wife and Servant.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
This name of Luce hath been ominous to me;
one Luce I should have married in the Country, and just
the night before, a toy took me in the head, and mounting
my Horse, I left Capons, Ducks, Geese, Poultry, Wildfowl,
Father, and Bride and all, and posted up to London,
where I have ever since continued Bachelor, till
now. And now --

body.stage: Enter Gratiana in haste, a Serving-man before her, and Taber after her.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.p:
Nay on, I prithee fellow on, my Father will wonder
where I have been visiting. Now, what had I forgot?
Taber, there is money, go to the Gold-smiths, bid him send
me my Fan; and make a quick return: on, fellow
on.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Her Fan at the Gold-smiths! now had I forgot
To ask her, his name, or his sign: but I will after
to know.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Sirrah, go call me back that Serving-man,
And ask him what is the Gentlewoman's name.

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p: I shall; ho, you: Friend, you.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Who is that calls?

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p: It was I.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Your business? you should be one, though not
of my cognisance, yet of my condition: a Serving-creature,
as I take it: pray what is your will with me?

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p:
Pray Sir, what might I call that Gentle-woman,
on whom you were attendant?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
You may call her what you please, but if you
call her otherwise then in the way of honesty, you may
perchance hear of it.

sp.speaker: Servingman.
sp.p:
Nay, be not offended: I say, what do
you call her?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Why Sir, I call her as it shall best please me,
sometimes young Lady, sometimes young Mistress; and what
hath any man to do with that?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Are you so captious, sirrah, what is her name?
Speak, and be brief.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Aye marry Sir, you speak, to purpose, and I can
resolve you: her name is Gratiana. But all this while I
have forgot my Mistress Fan.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Gratiana! oft have I heard of her, but saw her
not till now: it is a pretty wench, a very pretty wench,
nay, a very, very, very pretty wench. But what a Rogue
am I, of a married man? nay, that have not been married
this six hours, and to have my shittle-wits run
a Woolgathering already? What would poor Luce
say if she should hear of this? I may very well call
her poor Luce, for I cannot presume of five pounds to
her portion: what a Coxcomb was I, being a Gentleman,
and well derived, to match into so beggarly a kindred?
What needed I to have grafted in the stock of
such a Choake Pear, and such a goodly Popering as
this to escape me? Escape me (said I?) if she do,
she shall do it narrowly: but I am married already, and
therefore it is not possible, unless I should make away
my wife, to compass her. Married! why who knows
it? I will out-face the Priest, and then there is none
but she and her Father, and their evidence is not
good in Law: and if they put me in suite, the best
is, they are poor, and cannot follow it. Aye marry Sir,
a man may have some credit by such a Wife as this:
I could like this marriage well, if a man might change
away his Wife, still as he is a weary of her, and cope
her away like a bad commodity: if every new Moon
a man might have a new Wife, that is every year a dozen,
But this, Till Death us depart, is tedious: I will
go a wooing to her, I will; but how shall I do for
jewels and tokens? Luce hath mine in her custody, money
and all; tush, I will juggle them from her well enough:
see, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Here is my Husband, I pray move him in it.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: It toucheth both our reputations nearly;
For buy his oft repair, now whilst the Marriage
Is kept from public knowledge, your good name
May be by Neighbours hardly censured of.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Thou art sad, thou art sad Luce: what, melancholy
already, ere thou hast had good cause to be merry, and knewest
what sport was.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I have great reason, when my name is tossed
In every Gossips mouth, and made a by-word
Unto such people as it least concerns.
Nay, in my hearing, as they pass along,
Some have not spared to brand my modesty,
Saying, There sits she whom young Chartley keeps.
There hath he entered late, betimes gone forth.
Where I with pride was wont to sit before,
I am now with shame sent blushing from the door.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Alas poor fool, I am sorry for thee, but yet cannot
help thee, as I am a Gentleman. Why say Luce, thou
losest now forty shillings worth of Credit, stay but a time,
and it shall bring thee in a thousand pounds worth of commodity.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Son, Son, had I esteemed my profit more
Than I have done my credit, I had now
Been many thousands richer: but you see,
Truth and good dealing bear an humble sail;
That little I enjoy, it is with quiet,
Got with good conscience, kept with good report:
And that I still shall labour to preserve.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: But do you hear me?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Nothing I will hear, that tends unto the ruin
Of mine, or of my Daughters honesty.
Shall I be held a Broker to lewd Lust,
Now in my wain of years?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Will you but hear me?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Not in this case. I that have lived thus long,
Reported well, esteemed a welcome Guest
At every burdened Table, there respected;
Now to be held a Pander to my Daughter?
That I should live to this!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: But hark you Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: A Bawd to mine own child!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: To my sweet Luce!

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Father?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Deal with me like a Son, then call me Father;
I that have had the tongues of every man
Ready to crown my Reputation:
The hands of all my Neighbours to subscribe
To my good like; and such as could not write,
Ready with Palsy and unlettered fingers,
To set their scribbling marks.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Why Father in Law?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Thou hadst a Mother Luce; it is woe with me
To say thou hadst, but hast not; a kind Wife,
And a good Nurse she was: she, had she lived
To hear my name thus canvased, and thus tossed,
Seven years before she died, I had been a Widower
Seven years before I was: Heaven rest her soul,
She is in Heaven I hope.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Why so now, these be good words, I knew these
storms would have a shower, and then they would cease.
Now if your anger be over, hear me.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Well, say on Son.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Stay but a Month, it is but foure Weeks; nay,
it is February, the shortest Month of the year, and in
That time I shall be at full age; and the Land being entailed,
my Father can disinherit me of nothing. Is
your spleen down now? Have I satisfied you? Well,
I see you choleric hasty men, are the kindest when
all is done. Here is such wetting of Hand-kerchers, he
weeps to think of his Wife, she weeps to see her Father
cry! Peace fool, we shall else have those claim kindred
of the Woman killed with kindness.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Well Son, my anger is past; yet I must tell you,
It grieves me that you should thus flight it off,
Concerning us, no such a dear degree.
In private be it spoke, my Daughter tells me,
She is both a Wife and Maid.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: That may be helped.
sp.p:
Now Luce, your Fathers pacified, will you be pleased? I
would endure a Quarters punishment for thee, and wilt
not thou suffer a poor Months penance for me? It is
but eight and twenty days, Wench; thou shalt fare
well all the time, drink well, eat well, lie well: come,
one word of comfort at the later end of the day.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yours is my fame, mine honour, and my heart
Linked to your pleasure, and shall never part.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Gramercy Wench, thou shalt wear this chain
No longer for that word, I will multiply the links in such
order, that it shall have light to shine about thy neck,
oftener than it doth: this jewel, a plain Bristowe
stone, a counterfeit. How base was I, that coming to
thee in the way of Marriage, courted thee with counterfeit
stones? Thou shalt wear right, or none: thou hast
no money about thee, Luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, I have the hundred pounds that you gave
me to lay up last.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Fetch it; let me see, how much branched Satin
goes to a Petticoat? and how much wrought Velvet
to a Gown? then for a Beaver for the City, and a Black bag
for the Country: I will promise her nothing, but if
any such trifles be brought home, let her not thank
me for them.
sp.l: Gramercy Luce.
sp.p:
Nay, go in, Gravity and Modesty,
ten to one but you shall hear of me, ere you see me
again.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
I know you kind, impute my hasty Language
unto my rage, not me.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Why, do not I know you, and do not I
know her? I doubt you will wish shortly that I had never
known either of you: now, what sayst thou, my
sweet Luce?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
My words are yours, so is my life: I am now
part of yourself, so made by Nuptial vows.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
What a Pagan am I, to practise such villainy against
this honest Christian! If Gratiana did come into
my thoughts, I should fall into a vain to pity her: but
now that I talk of her, I have a tongue to woo her, Tokens
to win her; and that done, if I do not find a trick, both
to wear her, and weary her, it may prove a piece of a
Wonder. Thou seest, Luce, I have some store of Crowns
about me, there are brave things to be bought in the City;
Cheapside, and the Exchange, afford variety and rarity.
This is all I will say now, but thou mayst hear
more of me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
Heaven speed you where you go Sir; shall we in?
Though not from scandal, we live free from Sin.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: I will in before.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: I am still in love with Luce, and I would know
An answer more directly: fie, fie, this Love
Hangs on me like an Ague, makes me turn fool.
Coxcomb and Ass: why should I love her, why?
A Rattle-Baby, Puppet, a slight toy,
And now I could go to buffets with myself,
And cuff this Love away: but see, that is Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I cannot shun him, but I will shake him off.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: As much to you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: I will use few words, Canst love me?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Deed Sir no.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Why then farewell, the way I came, I will go.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: This is no tedious Courtship, he is soon answered,
So should all Suitors else be, were they wise;
For being repulsed, they do but waste their days
In thankless suites, and superficial praise.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Swear that thou wilt not love me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Not Sir, for any hate I ever bare you,
Or any foolish pride, or vain conceit:
Or that your feature doth not please mine eye,
Or that you are not a brave Gentleman:
But for concealed reasons I am forced
To give you this cold answer; and to swear
I must not, then with patience pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: Even farewell then.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: The like to you, and save your hopes in me.
Heaven grant you your best wishes; all this strife
Will end itself, when I am known a Wife.

body.stage: Enter Sir Harry, M. Harringsfield Gratiana with others.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
I am satisfied good Master Harringsfield touching
your friend, and since I see you have left his dangerous
company, I limit you to be a welcome guest unto my
Table.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: You have been always noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Taber: the news with thee.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
May it please the right worshipful to understand
that there are some at the Gate who dance a turn or two
without, and desire to be admitted to speak, with you
within.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: The Scholar is it not.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Nay sir, there are two Scholars, and they are spouting
Latin one against the other; And in my simple Judgment
the stranger is the better Scholar, and is somewhat
too hard for sir Boniface: For he speaks louder, and that
you know is ever the sign of the most learning, and he
also hath a great desire to serve your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
Two scholars; My house hath not place for
two, thus it shall be. Taber admit them both, we though
unlearned will hear them two dispute, and he that of the
two seems the best read, shall be received, the other
quite cashiered.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p:
In that you show but Justice, in all persons
merit should be regarded.

body.stage: Enter Taber ushering sir Boniface and Sencer, disguised like a pedant.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Et tu domini calve, iterum atque, iterum salve,
Amo amas amavi, sweet Lady Heaven save ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
This approves him to be excellent, but I
thank my breeding I understand not a word, you tong-men
you whose wealth lies in your brains; Not in your budgets
hear mw: Be it known, my house affords room
for one Schoolmaster but not for more. And I am thus
resolved, take you that side gentle sir Boniface, and sir possess
you that.
he of you two in arguing proves the best. To him will
I subscribe are you agreed.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nec animo, nec corde, nec vtroque.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
No more of that nec corde, noble Knight, he
wishes you nec corde, think of that.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: A Cord about my neck, sir Boniface.
Speak do you use me well.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: Domine currogas :

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: Is this to be endured, to call a Knight.
Cur, Rogue and Ass.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: I find myself abused.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p:
Yet patience good sir Harry, and hear more
pray sir Boniface: of what University?
Were you of.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I was student in Brazen nose.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p:
A man might guess so much by your pimples,
and of what place were you:

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Petrus dormit securus; I was Sir of Peeter house

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p:
Natus eram, in Woxford, and I proceeded
in Oxford.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Est mihi bene nostrum, thou wouldst say,
in Gotam; For my part sir Harry, I can read Service and
Marry, Que genus et flexum, though I go in genes Fustian,
scalpellum et charta I was not brought up at Plough and
cart, I can reach ui mihi, and neither laugh nor tee-hee,
sed as in present, if your worship at this present, Iste, Ista
Istud , will do me any good, to give me legem pone in
Gold or in money. Piper atque papauer , I will deserve it with
my labour.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: But when go you to dispute.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p:
Nomnativo hic prediculus, his words are
most ridiculous: But tu thou, qui the which, deridest those
that be rich, construe hanc sententiam, construe me this
sentence. Est modus in rebus sunt certi denique fines:

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Est modus in rebus: There is mud in the rivers.
Sunt certi denique fines, and certain little Fishes.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: I warrant you he hath his answer ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Dij boni boni.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p:
He will give you more bones than those to
gnaw on Sir Boniface.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Kartere Moosotropos Poluphiltate phile poetatis
Tes Logikes recoon, onch elashiste sophoon.
That is as much as to say, in our maternal lingua
I will make you sir Boniface, confess yourself an Ass in
English, speak open and broad words, for want of Latin,
and Denique instruct me to resolve such questions as I
shall ask you in our modern tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
confess him an Ass, speak obscene words
after entreat thee to resolve thy questions.
Do that, possess the place.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Di do and dum: No more words but mum:

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Noble sir Harry; Nunquam sic possit?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
Sir Boniface is sick already and calls for a
possit, no marvel, being so threatened.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
You Boniface, decline me I am a no after the
first conjugation, amo amavi, vocito vocitavi.
Titubo titubavi?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: I am not the preceptor to a pupil.
But can decline it, mark sir Timothy:
I am a no,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Bene bene.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: I am an as?

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Most true most true, vos estis, ut egosum testis,
That what he confessed is, as true as the pestis.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
This Scholar works by magic he hath
made him confess himself an Ass.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Per has meas manus vir, tues insanus,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
I will make him fret worse yet; Sir Boniface:
quid est grammatica.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Grammatica est ars,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, no more of these words good sir
Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Attend again, proceed me with this verse
of reverent Cato: Si deus estanimus

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: Nobis ut carmina dicunt.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Di quoth ha, out on him for a beastly man.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
I would not have him teach my children so
For more than I am worth.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p: O! but reverend sir Harry you must subaudi.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
I will never be so bawdy whilst I live,
nor any of mine I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: O Propria quae maribus:

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
By Boniface, it is those marrowbones,
That makes you talk so broadly?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: Venerabilis vir homo ille est ebrius.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: What doth he mean by that.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: He saith, I can speak Hebrew

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: But if sir Boniface still con these lessons,
He will speak the French tongue perfie.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Now to the last, I will task sir Boniface,
but with an easy question. Tell me sir:
What is Latin for this Earth?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p:
Facile and easy more fit for the pupil than
the preceptor: what is Latin for this Earth?
Tellus.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Tell you; no sir, it belongs to you to tell me.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p: I say Tellus is Latin for the Earth.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
And I say, I will not tell you what is Latin for
the Earth; unless you yield me victor:

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: You have no reason: good sir Timothy,
The place is yours.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.l: He hath deserved it well.

sp.speaker: Senser.
sp.l: But I will deserve it better, why this fellow
Is Frantic, you shall hear me make him speak
Idly and without sense. I will make him say,
His Nose was Husband to a Queen,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Sir Timothy not possible.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.l: He will not speak it for shame.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: That you shall hear; Magister Boniface.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: Quid ais domine Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Who was Pasiphas husband Queen of Creete.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p:
Who knows not that, why Minos was
Her Husband.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: That his nose was; did I not tell you so.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: I say that Minos was:

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: That his Nose was ha has.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: I will not believe it. Sir Boniface,
there are a brace of Angels.
You are not for my turn sir Timothy.
You are the man shall read unto my daughter
The Latin tongue, in which I am ignorant:
Confess yourself an Ass; speak bawdy words;
And after to talk idly. Hence away:
You shall have my good word, but not my pay?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: Opusest vsus ; sir Timothy you abuse us.
I swear by a noun, had I thy hose down,
Qui que quod, I would so smoke thee with the rod:
Ille Illa Illud, until I fetch blood.
But Nobiles valete , remain in quiet.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Sir Timothy, there is some Gold in earnest,
I like you well take into your tuition,
My daughter Gratiana; the news Taber.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Of another gallant noble sir that pretends to have
business, both with you and my mistress,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Admit him.

body.stage: Enter Chartly very gallant, in his hand a Lady.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Lusty Iuventus; will it please you to draw near.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Noble Knight, whilst you peruse that sweet
Lady, tell me how you like this:

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.l: You press so suddenly upon me sir
I know not what to answer.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Mad Chartly; what makes desperation here.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
To the word wooer let me add the name speeder
my father hath written to your father, and the cause of his
writing at this present, is to let you understand, that he
fears you have lived a maid too long: and therefore to
prevent all diseases incident to the same; as the green
sickness and others. He sent me like a skilful Physician,
to take order with you against all such maladies. If you will
not credit me, list but how fervently my father writes in
my behalf.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
He is my only son, and she I take as
your only daughter, what should hinder then,
To make a match between them, (well it is well it is good
I like it) I will make her Jointure three hundred pounds
a year.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
How say you by that sweet Lady three hundred
pounds a year and a proper man to boot.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: All is good, I like it, welcome Master Chartly.
Thou Gratiana art no child of mine
Unless thou biddest him welcome. This I presume
To be your fathers hand.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: But I will be sworn he never writ it.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: And this his seal at Arms.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Or else I understand it very poorly, but Lady
In earnest of further acquaintance, receive this Chain,
These Jewels, hand and heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
Refuse no Chain nor Jewels, heart nor hand,
but in exchange of these bestow thyself thine own
dear self upon him.

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.p:
Myself on him, whom I tell now I never saw?
Well since I must, your will is to me a law.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Nay then it is time to speak, shall I stand here
waiting like a Coxcomb, and see her given away before
my face? stay your hand sir Harry; and let me claim my
promise.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
My promise I will perform sir Timothy,
you shall I have all your wages duly paid.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.l: I claim fair Gratiana by your promise.
No more sir Timothy, but Sencer now,
You promised me when you received my service,
And with your liberal hand did wage my stay:
To endow me freely with your daughters Love,
That promise now I claim.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Mere cozenage, knavery,
I tide myself to no conditions.
In which such guile is practised, come son Chartly.
To cut of all disasters incident.
To these proceedings we will solemnise
These Nuptial rites with all speed possible.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Farewell good sir Timothy, farewell
learned sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Why: and farewell learned sir Timothy.
For now sir Timothy and I am two:
Boast on, brag on, exalt exalt thyself,
Swim in a Sea of pleasure and content
Whilst my Bark suffers wrack I will be revenged,
Chartly; I will cry vindicta for this Horn,
Next time thou goest, it must be with thy horn,

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: I am mad, and know not at what.
I could swagger but know not with whom,
I am at odds with myself; and know not why:
I shall be pacified, and cannot tell when,
I would fain have a wife but cannot tell where,
I would fasten on Luce but cannot tell how.
How; where; when; why; whom; what.
Feeding sure makes me lean, and fasting fat.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Not all this while once see me.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.l: His occasions, perhaps enforce his absence.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: His occasions:
Unless he find occasion of new Love.
What could enforce such absence from his spouse:
Am I grown foul and black, since my espousal's.
It should not seem so; For the shop is daily,
Customed with store of Chap-men, such as come
To cheapen Love. O no, I am myself?
But Chartly he is changed.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.l: You know that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Escape him if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: He cannot, I arrest you;

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: At whose suite.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Not at mine own, that is dashed, I love thee not.
Thou art a Spaniard, Gypsy, a mere Blackamoor:
Again, I say I love thee not.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: A Blackamoor, a Gypsy?
Sure I am changed indeed, and that the cause
My Husband left me so, this Gentleman
Once termed me beautiful, how look I Ioseph.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.l: As well as ever you did, fat, fresh, and fair.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: You lie boy, pocket that, and now be gon.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.l: And what shall then become of my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: I will wait upon your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I know you will not wait on such a Gypsy.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Yes Luce on such a Gypsy: Boy, abi abi.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p:
Abide sir, you need not fear that I have no
purpose to leave her.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Now you are going to the wedding-house.
You are bid to be a Bride maid, are you not.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What wedding sir, or whose?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p:
Why Chartleyes; Luce hath he been thy friend
so long, and would not bid thee to wait on his Bride.
Why lookest thou red and pale, and both, and neither.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: To Mr. Chartleyes Bridals, why, to whom,
Should he be married.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: To Grace of Gracious street.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: To Gratiana?
