Beshrew you sir you do not use me well,
To buzz into mine ears these strange untruths:
I tell you sir, it is as impossible
That they two should match: as Earth and Heaven to meet.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: You will not believe it, pray then hark within,
The Nuptial music echoing to their joys.
But you give credit to no certainties:
I told you but a tale, a lie, a fable?
A monstrous, a notorious idle untruth,
That you were black, and that I loved you not.
And you could credit that.
sp.stage: Enter sir Harry and Harings-field, Chartly leading Gratiana by the Arm, Taber and attendants.
sp.l: Who is tell-troth now.
Know you that man, or know you that fine Virgin:
Whom by the arm he leads.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I will not indure it: Heaven give you joy sir:

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: I thank you: Luce?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Look to the Maid she faints.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: Grace, come not near her Grace.
Father keep off, on Gentlemen apace.
She is troubled with the falling sickness, for
Oft hath she fallen before me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Nay if it be no otherwise, on gentlemen.
Let those with her strive to recover her.
Keep off, the disease is infectious:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
If it were in a man, it were nothing, but the
falling sickness in a woman is dangerous.

My tother father in Law, now shall I be utterly shamed,
If he assure to know me, I will out face him.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Son you are well met.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: How fellow.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: I cry you mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: No harm done friend, no harm done.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p:
If he? he could not but have known me there,
Yet he was wondrous like him.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.l: How cheer you Luce, whence grew this passion.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I do not know myself:
I am apt to swoon, and now the fit is past me.
I thank you for your help; is master Chartly

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p:
Yes: and to supply his place, see where thy father
comes.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: He hath not such a suit, besides this gallant
Led by the arm a Bride, a lusty Bride?
How much might I have wronged the Gentleman.
By craving his acquaintance, this it is,
To have dim Eyes. Why looks my daughter sad.
I cry you mercy. Sir I saw not you.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
I would I had not seen you at this time neither,
farewell.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: If he be gone? then call me vent my grief,
Father I am undone,

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Forbid it Heaven.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Disgraced, despised, discarded, and cast off.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: How, mine own child:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: My Husband, O my husband?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: What of him.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Shall I the shower of all my grief at once
Power out before you: Chartly, once my husband
Hath left me to my shame. Him and his Bride,
I met within few minutes.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Sure it was they.
I met them two, it was he; base villain Jew.
I will to the Wedding board, and tell him so:
I will do it as I am a man?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Be not so rash.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: I will live and die upon him;
He is a base fellow, so I will prove him too.
Ioseph my Sword.
This rashness will undo us.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I will have my Sword.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: It hath been twice in France, and once in Spaine,
With Iohn a Gaunt, when I was young like him
I had my wards, and foins, and quarter-blows:
And knew the way into St. Georges fields.
Twice in a morning, Tuttle, Finsbury?
I knew them all, I will to him, where is my sword,
Or leave this spleen, or you will overthrow
Our fortunes quite, let us consult together,
What we were best to do.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: I will make him play at Leap-frog, well I hear thee

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I cannot prove our marriage, it was secret,
And he may find some cavil in the Law.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: I will to him with no Law, but Staffood Law.
I will ferret the false boy, nay on good Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Part of your spleen, if you would change to counsel,
We might revenge us better.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Well I hear thee.

sp.speaker: Lude.
sp.l: To claim a public marriage at his hands:
We want sufficient proof, and then the world
Will but deride our folly, and so add
Double disgrace unto my former wrong.
To Law with him he hath a greater purse,
And nobler friends, how then to make it known?

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: Is this his damasked kirtle fringed with Gold,
His black bag, and his Beaver, it is well yet
I have a Sword:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: And I have a project in my Brain begot,
To make his own mouth witness to the World
My innocence, and his incontinence?
Leave it to me, I will clear myself from blame,
Though I the wrong, yet he shall reap the shame.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p:
Now or never, look about thee Sencer, tomorrow
is the Marriage day which to prevent, lies not within the
compass of my apprehension, therefore I have thus disguised
myself, to go to the Looming woman's, the Fortune
tellers. The anything, the nothing, this over against mother
Red-caps is her house, I will knock.

body.stage: Enter 2. Luce in her boyes shape.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Who is there? What would you have.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: I would speak with the wise gentlewoman of the house.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: O belike you have lost somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: You are in the wrong sweet youth.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I am somewhat thick of hearing, pray speak out.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
I say I have not lost anything, but wit and time,
And neither of those she can help me too:

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Then you belike are crossed in Love, and come to
know what success you shall have.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it sweet lad; thou hast hit it.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: What is it, you say sir:

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I pray come in, I will bring you to my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
This is the house, knock Ioseph, my business
craves dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ioseph.
sp.p:
Now am I as angry, as thou art timorous, and
now to vent the next thing I meet, O it is the door.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: Who is there, what are you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: A maid and a wife.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: And that would grieve any wench to be so,
I know that by myself, not Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Boy, where is your Mistress.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: In some private talk with a Gentleman?
I will fetch her to you presently.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: If she and you see me not, I am but dead,
I shall be made, a by-word to the World:
The scorn of women; and my Fathers shame:

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p:
You tell me your name is Sencer, I knew it
before, and that Chartly is to be married,
I could have told it you.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Married tomorrow, O me!

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
By but you tell me, that Chartly before tomorrow
shall be disappointed of his, make that good,
Thou shalt have twenty Angels.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p:
I will do it, stand aside, I will have but a word or
two with this Gentlewoman; and I am for you presently.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O! Mother, mother.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
My husband marry another wife tomorrow?
O changeable destiny, no sooner married to him, but instantly
To loose him. Nor death it grieves me so much that
I am a wife, but that I am a maid too, to carry one of them
well is as much as any is bound to do, but to be tide to
both, is more than flesh and blood can endure.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p:
Well trust to me, and I will sell all things
straight.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p:
Where is this Witch, this hag, this beldam, this
wizard, and have I found thee, thus then will I tear, mumble
and maul thee.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: Help, help, and if you be a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Forbear this rudeness, he that touches her,
Draws against me.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Against you sir, apply thou, that shall be tried.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Help, help, part them help.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: With patience hear her speak.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
Sencer.
sp.p:
Than trince of all sides, if we come for counsel,
Let us with patience hear it:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Then first to me.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
You would prevent young Chartlyes marriage,
you shall: hark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: It pleaseth me.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: You forestall Gratianes wedding, it is but thus.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
You would enjoy Luce as your wife, and lie with
her tomorrow night. Hark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Fiat.

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p:
Away, you shall enjoy him, you are married,
Luce away, you shall see Chartly discarded from Gratiana,
Sencer be gon, and if I fail in any of these or the rest,
I lay myself open to all your displeasures.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: Farewell till soon:

sp.speaker: Wisewoman.
sp.p: You know your meeting place.

sp.speaker: Wiseoman.
sp.p:
You shall report me wiser and cunning
too.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
I will add one night more to the time, I have said.
I have not many I hope to live a maid.

body.stage: Enter Taber and sir Boniface with a Trencher, with broken meat and a Napkin.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, what a time of trouble is this tomorrow
tomorrow is my mistress to be married, and we serving-men
are so puzzled.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: The dinner is half done, and before I say
Grace, and bid the old Knight and his guest proface.
A medicine from your trencher, good Master

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.l: As good a man as ever was sir Saber:
sp.p:
Well think it no shame, men of learning and wit, say study
gets a stomach, friend Taber a bit.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Lick clean good sir Boniface, and save the scraper
a labour.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.l: But soft let me ponder:
Know you him that comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Most heartily welcome, would you speak with
any here.

sp.speaker: Senc.
sp.p: Pray is the young gentleman of the house at leisure.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Mean you the Bridegroom Master Chartly.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
I have a Letter for him. You seem to be a gentleman
yourself, acquaint him with my attendance, and I
shall rest yours in all good offices.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Sir Boniface, pray keep the gentleman company
I will first acquaint your lips with the virtue of the
Seller.

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p:
Adesdem come near, and taste of your beer.
Welcome, sine dole, for puntis te vole,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: When I taste of your liquor.
Gramercy master Vicar.

body.stage: Enter Taber with a bowle of Beere and a Napkine.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p:
Most heartily welcome: your courtesy I beseech
you, ply it off I entreat you, pray sir Boniface keep the
Gentleman company; till I acquaint my young master with
his business.

sp.speaker: Sir Bonif.
sp.p:
Taber, I shall be solas manus.
They dissemble one to another.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: A vostre servitor.

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p: He what art thou,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: A banger on, if it please you:

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p:
And I a shaker off, I will not bear your gallows,
You shall not hang on me.
sp.stage: Enter Chartly with his Napkin as from Dinner.
sp.p: O. Mr. Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, the Ladies call upon you to dance,
they will be out of measure displeased, if dinner being
done, you be not ready to lead them a measure:

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.p:
Indeed women love not to be scanted of
their measure.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Fie sir Boniface: have you forgot yourself,
Whilst you are in the Hall, there is never a whetstone for
their wits in the Parlour?

sp.speaker: Sir Boniface.
sp.p:
I will enter and set an edge upon their
Engines.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
To me sir, from whom? a letter to her most
dear, most loving, most kind friend Mr. Chartly these be
delivered: sure from some wench or other I long to know
the contents.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Now to cry quittance with you for my farewell
learned sir Timothy.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Good news, as I live, there is for thy pains my
good sir Pandarus: Hadst thou brought me word my father
had turned up his heels. Thou couldst scarcely have
pleased me better:

though I disclaim the
name of wife, of which I account myself altogether unworthy,
yet let me claim some small interest in your love,
this night I lie at the house where we were married, (the
Wisewomans I mean) where my maiden-head is to be
rifled, bid fair for it, and enjoy it, see me this night or never,
so may you marrying Gratiana, and loving me, have
a sweet wife and a true friend: This night or never, your
quondam wife: Hereafter your poor sweet-heart no other:
Luce. So when I am tired with Gratiana, that is when I
am past grace. With her I can make my rendezvous, I will not
slip this occasion, nor sleep till I see her, thou art an honest
lad, and mayst prove a good Pimp in time. Canst thou
advise me what colour, I may have to compass this commodity.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Sir, she this night expects you, and prepares a
costly banquet for you.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
I will go, although the Devil and mischance look
big,

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Feign some news that such a piece of Land is
fallen to you, and you must instantly ride to take possession
of it, or which is more probable, cannot you persuade them
you have received a letter that your Father lies a dying.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
You rogue, I would he did but the name of
That news is called, too good to be true.

sp.speaker: Sencer
sp.p:
And that if ever you will see him alive, you must
ride post into the Country.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Enough: if ever I prove Knight errant thou
shalt be mine own proper squire, for this thou hast fitted
me with a plot, do but wait here note how I will manage
it,
Tabor my horse, for I must ride tonight.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.p: Tonight sir.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
So tell my Bride and Father, I have news that
quite confounds my senses.

body.stage: Enter Sir Harry, Gratiana and Harringsfield.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: How ride tonight, the marriage day tomorrow
And all things well provided for the feast.
O tell me sweet, why do you look so pale.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: My Father, O my Father:

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: What of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: What of your father, Son?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: If ever I will hear his aged tongue.
Preach to me counsel, or his palsy hand,
Stroke my wild head, and bless me, or his eyes:
Drop tear by tear which they have often done,
At my misgoverned rioting youth.
What should I more, if ever I would see;
The good old man alive. O, O?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Go thy ways for thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: But do you mean to ride.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: By Grace, all this night.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Not all the night without alighting sure:
you will find more in it than to get up and ride,

sp.speaker: Harring.
sp.l: The Gentleman's riding, boots and spurs.
Why Tabor?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: Nay Grace, now is no time.
To stand on scrupulous parting. Knewest thou my business.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: As she shall know it:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: And how I mean this night to toil myself.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Marry hang you brock.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: Thou would be moan my travel.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: I know it would grieve her:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
You father, Grace, good Mr. Harringsfield.
You sir, and all pray for me Gentlemen, that in this dark
nights journey I may find smooth way, sweet speed and
all things to my mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: We will see my son take horse.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: But I will stay.
I want the heart to see him post away?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
Save you gentlewoman, I have a message to deliver
To one Mistress Gratiana, this should be the Knights
house her father.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: It is: The message that you have to her.
You may acquaint me with, for I am one
That knows the inside of her thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Are you the Lady,

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: Sir I am the poor gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: There is a conning woman dwells not far.
At Hogsden Lady, famous for her skill.
sp.p:
Besides some private talk that much concerns your fortunes
in your love. she hath to show you this night if it
shall please you walk so far as to her house, an admirable
suite.
sp.l: Of costly needle work, which if you please.
You may by under-rate for half the value
It cost the making, about six a clock.
You may have view thereof, but otherwise.
A Lady that hath craved the sight thereof:
Must have the first refusal.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: I will not fail her.
My husband being this day rid from home.
My leisure fitly serves me, thank you Mistress?

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: At six o'clock.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: I will not fail the hour.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Now to sir Harry, his is the next place.
To meet at Hogsden his fair daughter Grace.

body.stage: Enter old M. Chartly as new come out of the Country To inquire after his Son, and three or foure serving men with blue Coats to attend him.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p:
Good heaven; This London is a stranger
grown, and out of my acquaintance, this seven years I
have not seen Pauls steeple, or Cheap, cross.

sp.speaker: Gyles.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: Hast thou not made inquiry for my Son.

sp.speaker: Gyles.
sp.p:
Yes sir, I have asked about every where for him,
But cannot hear of him.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p:
Disperse yourselves, inquire about the Taverns,
Ordinaries, Bowl-alleys, Tennis courts, Gaming-houses.
For there (I fear) he will be found.

sp.speaker: Gyles.
sp.p: But where shall we hear of your worship again.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p:
At Grace Church by the Conduit, near sir
Harry, but stay, leave off a while your bootless search, had
every man such a wild brain to his sorrow, of such small
hope, who when he should have married a fair, a modest,
and a virtuous maid, rich and revenueed well, and even
the night before the marriage day, took horse, road thence
whether Heaven knows, since the distracted virgin hath
left her Fathers house, but never found, yet in their search
we have measured out much Ground.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Your worship will be there.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Yes, not to fail.
At half an hour past six, or before seven.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p:
You shall not find us at six and at seven, I will
Warrant you: good health to your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Farewell good fellow,
At the Wisewomans house I know it well:
Perhaps she knows some danger touching me.
I will keep mine hour.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Sir Harry, a hand a hand to balk you it were siun.
I shall be bold to make your house mine Inn:

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Brother Chartly; I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Methinks sir Harry you look strangely on me.
And do not bid me welcome with an heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: And blame me not to look amazedly,
To see you here.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Why me?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Come come, ye are welcome.
And now I will turn my strangeness to true joy,
I am glad to see you well, and safe recovered,
Of your late grievous sickness.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: The strange amazed looks that you cast off
You put on me, and blame me not to wonder,
That you should talk of sickness to found men,
I thank my stars, I did not taste the grief
Of inward pain or outward malady,
This seven years day.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: But by your favour brother,
Then let me have my wonder back again.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Before I quite part with it, let me know,
Why you the name of brother put upon me.
In every clause, a name as strange to me:
As my recovered sickness,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: You are pleasant,
And it becomes you well, welcome again,
The rather you are come just to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: What wedding sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: That you should ask that question:
Why of my daughter Grace.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Is Grace bestowed? Of whom I pray,

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Of whom, but of your son.
I wonder brother Chartly, and my friend,
You should thus play on me.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: But by your favour,
Were you tenue Knights Sir Harry, (take me with you)
My son match with your daughter, my consent,
Not worthy to be craved.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Nay, then I see:
sp.p:
You will stir my patience, know this forward match took
its first birth from you.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: From me?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: From you.
Peruse this letter, know you your own hand.
It was well that I reserved, your hand a witness
Against your tongue, you had best deny the Jointure,
Of the three hundred pounds made to my daughter,
It is that I know you aim at, but your seal.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Shall not make me approve it, I deny
This Seal for mine, nor do I vouch that hand,
Your daughter and the dower, letter and all
I quite disclaim, sir Harry you much wrong me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
I can bear more than this, heap wrong on
Wrong, and I will support it all, I for this time
sp.l: Will cast my spleen behind me, and yet hear me,
This letter your son Chartly as from you,
Delivered me. I like the motion well.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: My spleen is further thrown aside than yours.
And I am full as patient, and yet hear me;
My son is contracted to another maid,
Nay I am patient still, yet that I writ
This letter sealed, this impress I deny.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Why then the jack your hand did counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p:
Why then he did so, where is that unthrift
speak?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Some hour ago, he mounted and rid post.
To give you visit whom he said lay sick
Upon your death-bed.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: You amaze me sir.
It is an ill presage, hereon I see.
Your former salutation took its ground:
To see me safe recovered of my sickness.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Indeed it did, your welcome is a subject.
I cannot use too oft, welcome again,
I am sorry you this night must sup alone:
For I am else-where called about some business,
Concerning what I know not, hours run on.
I must to Hogsden, high time I were gone.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Perhaps to the Wisewomans, she may tell me.
The fortunes of my son, this accident,
Hath bred in me suspicion, and strange fears.
I will not sup alone, but I protest,
amongst some this night. I will play the intruding guest.

body.stage: Enter the Wisewoman, Sencer, Luce and her Father, 2. Luce.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: But will sir Harry come.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Presume he will, and Chartly too.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.l: I will have the knave by the ears.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Nay patience sir, leave your revenge to me.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Granam I am come according to promise.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: And welcome to the best hole that I have in Hogsden.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Good even.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Thanks sir, a good even may it prone,
That each may reap the fruits of their own Love:

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: That shall be my prayer too.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Come what shall us do.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: Withdraw, I will place you all in several rooms.
Where sit, see, but say nothing.

sp.speaker: Taber.
sp.l: Here sweet Mistress, I know the place well ver
Since I was here to know my fortune.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: Call me some half an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
Your Ladyship is most lovingly welcome. A low
stool for the Gentlewoman boy: I made bold to send to
you to take view of such a piece of work, as I presume
you have seldom seen the like.

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.p: Of whose doing, I pray.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
A friend of yours and mine. Please you withdraw
I will bring you to it.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: One calls sweet Lady, I shall do you wrong,
But pray you think my little stay not long:

body.stage: Enter Sencer, sir Harry and Luce.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Here sir in this retiring Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Gramercy friend, how now; what is here to do
A pretty wench and a close chamber too.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: That you have so much graced my Mothers house,
With your desired presence worthy Knight.
Receive a poor Maids thanks, who is there? a chair
And cushion for sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Thanks most fair.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Please you but a few minutes here to stay:
Till my return, I will not be long away.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: The gentlewoman will wait on you by and by sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: And I will attend her friend,
Of all those doubts I long to know the end:

body.stage: Enter 2. Luce and old Chartly. M

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
The Knight you seek was here, or will be
straight, and if you be the man you name yourself.
sp.l: You are most welcome, and you shall not back,
Till you have scene sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p:
Gentle youth.
I saw him enter here, and under privilege of his acquaintance
made I hold to stay.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: And you are welcome sir, sit down I pray.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
Now they are placed in several rooms, that look
Into this one, Were Chartly come we had all our company.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.l: Hark, there is one knocks it is Chartly on my life.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: One of you let him in whilst I prepare me
To entertain his coming.

body.stage: Enter young Chartly, Vsherd in by Sencer.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
What? old acquaintance Luce. Nor a word?
Yet some lip labour if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: My Husband?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: What young Chartly?

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: How? My son.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Come, come away with this wailing in woe, if
thou puttest finger in the eye a little longer, I shall plunge in
pain too presently.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Husband?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p: What sayst thou my sweet wife,

sp.speaker: Graciana.
sp.p: Wife? O my heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: In that name wife I claim a poor child's part.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: O husband; How have you used me?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Nay how do I mean to use thee: But as a man
Should use his wife.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.p: I hope he doth not mean to use her so.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: I hope so too,

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: My granam is a Witch.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Nay Luce, sweet wife leave weeping if thou
lovest me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
O can you blame me, knowing that the fountain
of all these Springs took their first head, from you, you
know, you too will know, not three days since are past,
since we were married.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: Married, I can endure no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: It is not possible.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: I will be even with thee, for this old granam.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: And though we wanted witness upon Earth,
Yet Heaven bears record of our Nuptial Tie.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Tush, when we meet in heaven let us talk of that.
Nay come you ass, you fool, what is past is past,
Though man and wife, yet I must marry now.
Another gallant, here is thy letter Luce.
And this night I intend to lodge with thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
I will scratch her eyes out first, although I love
Her.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Prithee be merry?
I have made a gull of Grace, and old sir Harry thinks me
a great way off, I told the Knight,
sp.l: My father lay a dying, took post horse,
Rid out of Holburne, turned by Islington,
So, hither wench to lodge all night with thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.l: Here is one saith nay to that,

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Was that your journey:

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: Why I have too much of Grace already.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.l: Thou hast no grace at all.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Nay let us to bed, if thou couldst but imagine how
I love thee Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p:
How is it possible you can love me, and go about
To marry another.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Dost thou not know she is rich? Why you
fool as soon as I have got her dower, it is but giving her
a dram, or a pill to purge melancholy to make her turn up
her heels, and then with all that wealth, come I to live with
thee my sweet rascal.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: She thanks you, and is much beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: Art thou my suitor? wouldst thou marry me,
And thy first wife alive, then poison me,
To purchase my poor dower.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
What shall I say, or think, or do, I am at a
Nonplus.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: Hast thou the face, thou brazen impudence,
To look upon me past grace.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: Thou canst not properly call me past grace, for
I never enjoyed thee yet. I cannot tell, whether
I blush or no, but I have now at this time,
More Grace, than I can tell what to do with.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: Who drew thee to this folly?

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Who but the old dotard thy Father, who when
I was honestly married to a civil maid, he persuaded
me to leave her, I was loath at first but after entreating, urging,
and offering me large proffers, I must confess I was
seduced to come a wooing to thee.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: My father, villain.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Aye thy father Grace. And were he here I would
Justify it to the old dotards face.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Vild boy thou darest not be so impudent.
When did I meet thee, seek or sue to thee:
When? Name the day, the month, the hour, the year.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Plots, plots. I can but cry you mercy both,
Say that I have done you wrong, I can be but sorry for it,
but indeed to clear you, and lay the fault where it ought
to be. All this comes from mine own father in the country,
who hearing I had married with Luce. Sends me
word of his blessing to be divorced from her, and to come a
suitor to your daughter, I think you have his hand and seal
to show.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: My hand and seal, when was that letter writ.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Heyda, if you get one word more of me tonight,
but scurvy looks, I will give you leave to hang me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: Vild boy.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Ungracious villain.

sp.speaker: Gratiana.
sp.l: Treacherous youth?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.l: No grace at all?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: No grace.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.l: This is bad company who hath seduced thee?
Speak on my blessing, who hath thus misled thee?
But no more lies I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Bid company hath been the shame of me, I was as
virtuously given as any youth in Europe, till I fell into one
Boysters company, it is he that hath done all the harm
upon me.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: And if he should deny it?

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p: What then you would cry him mercy.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
I had best bite out my tongue and speak no more
what shall I do, or what shall I say, there is no out facing
them all: Gentlemen, Fathers, wives, or what else. I have
wronged you all. I confess it that I have, what would you
more, will any of you rail of me? I will bear it, will any of
you beat me? So they strike not too hard. He suffer it,
will any of you challenge me? I will answer it. What would
you have me say, or do? One of these I have married, the
other I have betrothed, yet both maids for me; Will you
have me take one, and leave the tother? I will, will you
have me keep them both? I will.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Perjured not mine.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
What you here too? Nay then I see all my good
friends are met together, wilt thou have me Luce? I am
thy Husband, and had I not loved thee better than Grace. I
had not disappointed the marriage day tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Lascivious no.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Wilt thou have me Grace, for had I not loved
thee better than Luce. I would never after I had married
her been contracted to thee.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Inconstant no,

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Then neither married man, widow nor bachelor,
what is to be done? here is even the proverb verified, between
two stools, the tail goes to ground.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p:
Now I bethink me this our meeting here
is wondrous strange, call in the Gentlewoman that owns
this house.

body.stage: Enter Sencer and the Wisewoman, he like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p:
Old trot, I will trounce thee.
Here is the marriage proved twixt Luce and Chartly, witch
this was not your promise.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
Have patience, and in the end we will pay you all.
Your worships are most heartily welcome, I made bold to
send for you, and you may see to what end, which was to
discover unto you, the wild vagaries of this, of this wanton
wag pasty, a wild-oats I warrant him, and sir Harry
that your daughter hath scaped this scoring, thank this
gentleman, and then make of him as he deserves.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: O, I remember him.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
He never pleased mine eye so well as now.
I know his Love, and he in Chartlyes place
My favour shall possess.

sp.speaker: Sencer.
sp.p: Thanks my sweet Grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
Aye and the more the inconstant youth to spite.
Sencer, I gave her thee in Chartlyes sight.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
There is one gone already, but this is my wife and
her I will keep in spite both of the Devil and his dam.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: Not from her lawful Husband.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: That am I.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
That is the Gentleman, accept him Luce.
And you then like of her, nay I will make it good,
This gentleman married you visarded, you him disguised
mistaking him for Chartly, which none but my boy lack
was privy to; after she changed her habit with him, is
you with lack.
And you in mistress Luces habit.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: May I believe you mother.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p: This be your token.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p: Her that I married, I wrong twice by the finger.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Of that token, my hand was sensible.

sp.speaker: Boyst.
sp.p:
And ere the clamorous and loud noise be gone,
I whispered to her thus.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You are the man,

sp.speaker: Boyster.
sp.p:
Thanks granam, what thou promised thou hast
done.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And leaving him, I take you for my son.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p:
Two gone, then where is the third, this makes me
mad, where is my wife then, for a wife I had.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.l: Not see thy wife. Come hither jack my boy.
Nay take him to thee, and with him all joy.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Well art thou served to be a general scorn,
To all thy blood: and if not for our sakes,
For thy souls health and credit of the world,
Have some regarded to me, to me thy father.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.l: Enough sir: if I should say I would become
A new man; You would not take my word.
If I should swear. I would amend my life,
sp.p:
You would not take mine oath, if I should bind myself,
To become an honest man you would scarce take my bond.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.p: I should do none of these.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Then see sir, when to all your judgments I see
me past grace, do I lay hold of Grace, and here begin to
retire myself, this woman hath lent me a glass, in which
I see all my imperfections, at which my conscience doth
more blush inwardly, than my face outwardly, and now I
dare confidently undertake for myself I am honest.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
Then I dare confidently undertake to help you
To a wife who desires to have an honest man or none, look
on me well, simple though I stand here I am your wife,
blush not at your folly man, perhaps I have more in me,
than you expect from me.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Knavery and riot both which, are now to me
mean forage.

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p:
You and I have been better acquainted and yet
search me not too far least you shame me, look on me
well, nay better, better yet, I will assure you I left off a petticoat
when I put on these breeches,
What say you now, she scatters her hair.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: First love, and best beloved?

sp.speaker: 2. Luce.
sp.p: Let me be both or neither.

sp.speaker: Wisew.
sp.p:
My boy turned girl I hope she will keep my
counsel from henceforth, I will never entertain any servant
but I will have her searched.

sp.speaker: Old Chart.
sp.l: Her love hath drawn her hither after him.
My loving daughter welcome thou hast run,
A happy course to see my son thus changed.

sp.speaker: Chartly.
sp.p:
Father, call me once again your son, and
sir Harry me your friend: Sencer an hand, and mistress
Grace an heart, in honourable love. Where I have wronged
you Luce forgive. Impute my errors to my youth not me,
with Grace I interchange, an embrace with you Luce, a
parting buss I wish you all joy, divide my heart amongst
you, thou my soul.
sp.l: Nay mother midnight there is some love for you.
Out of thy folly, being reputed wise,
We self conceited have our follies found:
Bear thou the name of all these comic acts.
Luce, Luce and Grace, (O covetous man) I see,
I sought to engross what now sufficeth three.
Yet each one wife, enough, one Nuptial Feast:
Shall serve three Bridals where, be thou chief guest.

div1.head: TO HIS CHOSEN FRIEND the learned Author Mr Thomas Heywood.
div1.l: Thou wants no Herald to divulge thy fame;
It needs no Apology; Only thy name;
Into judicious Readers, doth infuse;
A will: to add a Laurel to thy muse;
Was now Maecaenas living. How would he
Support thy learned wit? Whose industry
Hath purchased such a knowing skill; That those
Who read admire thee; less some Critic shows
His Ignorance in seeking with new songs,
To gain the honour; which to thee belongs.
But let pale envy belch forth all her spite
Thy Candid same shall still continue white
Unspotted, pure, and Fair, till memory,
Be turned oblivion, or a Deity,
Prove mortal; And when Atropos shall do
The fat all office, her belongs unto;
Apollo will rebreathe a life in thee,
In length to equal all eternity
Where in Elyzian joys he will so raise
Thy worth where never wither shall the bays
Wherewith he crowns thee; So thy works will show.
The Debt, I pay is no more but what I owe.
